item.title: Ticket #1622 (Pingbacks/Trackbacks/Enclosures should be done on shutdown) created

item.title: Ticket #1619 (Tab highlight issue ) closed
item.dc:creator: schulte
item.description:
fixed:

If you comment out line 26 of wp-admin/post.php, this menu tab issue goes away. 

	// Fix submenu highlighting for pages.
//if (false !== strpos($_SERVER['HTTP_REFERER'], 'edit-pages.php')) $submenu_file = 'page-new.php';

What I don't know is if you remove that code, does something else get jammed up elsewhere...might be some remnant code.

item.title: Ticket #1621 (database: posts.ID and comments.comment_post_ID don't match) created
item.dc:creator: dougal
item.description: The posts.ID field is defined as an UNSIGNED bigint(20), but the comments.comment_post_ID field is a signed int(11).

item.title: Ticket #1620 (Scheduled entries on Dashboard not ordering correctly.) created
item.dc:creator: schulte
item.description:
Let unfixed, the Scheduled Entries text on the Dashboard yields a list of entries in the order they were created instead of the correct post date/time order.

original wp-admin/index.php code: 

if ( $scheduled = $wpdb->get_results("SELECT ID, post_title, post_date_gmt FROM $wpdb->posts WHERE post_status = 'publish' AND post_date_gmt > '$today'") ) :

corrected query: 

if ( $scheduled = $wpdb->get_results("SELECT ID, post_title, post_date_gmt FROM $wpdb->posts WHERE post_status = 'publish' AND post_date_gmt > '$today' ORDER BY post_date_gmt") ) :

item.title: Ticket #1619 (Tab highlight issue ) created
item.dc:creator: eragle
item.description: Go to Manage / Manage Pages. Now jump back to Write. You are at the Write Post page, but the Write Page tab is highlighted by accident.

item.title: Ticket #1618 (TinyMCE won't accept <del> and <ins> tags) created
item.dc:creator: seth
item.description: I use <del> and <ins> tags a lot in my writing. TinyMCE has no button for them, so I inserted them in its HTML mode. When I click "Update", it strips the <del> and <ins> tags out :(

item.title: Ticket #1617 (CSS adjustment in wp-admin. Necessary for maintaining good presentation.) created
item.dc:creator: Podz
item.description:
Presentation > Theme editor

If the name of the theme is long, the size of the text looks ugly.

The attached patches:

*theme-editor.patch

*it applies a new h2 class to the actual code (the variable %s)

*wp-admin-css.patch

*defines the new class 'h2.themename' and gives it a font-size of 20px. This is 10px less than was being applied.

Other text that used the h2 tag had no variable lengths so they were not a problem. The patch does force a line break, but I've not done this stuff before so digging deeper to stop that may not be warranted.

One thought though: given that the theme-editor only edits files actually in /wp-content/themes, why are we displaying that information so fully ?

item.title: Ticket #1020 (Presentation area shows raw CSS instead of Theme/Author names) updated
item.dc:creator: muskie
item.description:
I too encountered this problem. I eventually fixed it. I could easily reproduce it if you like. I cut and pasted some text into a new text file I created with BBEdit. At the time I had line endings to be Mac. I've switched to Unix line endings. I did't even need any CSS just putting in the Theme information in the comment will demonstrate this problem.

Muskie

item.title: Ticket #1525 (Kubrik Achive Format Problem) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: This is done on purpose and is part of the Kubrick navigation style. All of the Kubrick templates are like this. #2808 should be reversed.

item.title: Ticket #1616 (.htaccess is not writable when in different directory then blog ...) created
item.dc:creator: ming
item.description:
On Dreamhost the .htaccess file is not writable by WordPress when the blog url and install url are different. That's because $_SERVERSCRIPT_FILENAME? returns 'php.cgi' instead of the script name (Note: only when your site is run as CGI instead of Apache - which is standard at Dreamhost).

(Why am I explaining this, I'm sure the whole PHP/CGI/Dreamhost thing is a constant thorn in your side. :-)

I've fixed this problem by adding the following line to get_home_path() $_SERVERSCRIPT_FILENAME? = $_SERVERDOCUMENT_ROOT?.$_SERVERSCRIPT_URL?;

Actually, I've now placed that in my wp-config.php file and everything still appears to be working (but I haven't tested fully).
